narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I became more comfortable analyzing sources. It was also extremely valuable to have access to people who were able to share their first-person knowledge of events and concepts related to the class.
Hear from people with a wide variety of perspectives and experiences with the topic of the week. Discussed some very challenging and controversial questions - found it super interesting!

I developed a better understanding of what terrorism means and the implications of using the term. Rather than simply designating a group or an individual solely for political expediency, I learned to use quantitative data to determine who should be designated as a terrorist.

I learned an incredible amount about terrorism. The course is well-organized; take a look at the syllabus and the topics there for an overview! Professor Weir is incredibly knowledgeable, both as an academic but also as a researcher with extensive relationships with people and communities involved in terrorism/political violence both in the US and in Ireland. We were able to speak with a number of people involved in conflicts and ask personal questions about their experiences, goals, and motivations.
I learnt about terrorism, specifically its definition and causes, and other thematic areas within the topic, like ISIS, right-wing terrorism, and civil rights.
I learned a lot about terrorism  how to comprehend it, the reasons behind it, why people become terrorists, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Loved it!
The format of the course makes it easy for everyone to be engaged with the material.

I thought this course was very well done. More feedback on the assignments would have been great, but as it was Professor Weir was very engaged with students and adapted the course well to being online. We were able to speak with practitioners, read a range of materials (without it being too much), etc. My one other suggestion would be to have access to the student powerpoints to have as a reference.

The greatest strength of this course is the speakers. Prof. Weir brings in "terrorists" and academic experts to talk to us about their experiences or work regarding the subject matter. We get to have a real conversation with them, which can be challenging yet very informative.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Extremely successful. Virtual discussion flowed smoothly and we were able to talk to speakers across the globe over zoom.
Thought the virtual seminar discussions were still very engaging and productive
Weekly student presentations for this course was very successful. Each student was able to present their slides over Zoom as they would during any other semester.

The interviews with the guest speakers were great, as were the powerpoints and class discussion. Professor Weir did a wonderful job adapting the course to COVID times. She is also a great seminar discussion leader.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!

Absolutely! Professor Weir is a queen, the subject matter is super interesting, the workload is very low, and the guest speakers/readings are carefully selected to contribute to the understanding of the material and to keep students interested.

Yes, this course really challenged my preconceptions about terrorism. Even with no political science or global background, this course was a great way to learn more about terrorism and its impact on U.S. domestic as well as foreign actions.
Yes!!

Yes. Most people use the term 'terrorist' without a proper understanding of what it means. The first assignment for the course was on the definition of terrorism, as each student understood it. We realized that each person's perception of terrorism is different, so we had to relearn what it really means to refer to others as terrorists.

I absolutely would recommend. If you want to learn about the topic, you will have a great experience with Professor Weir and meet all the learning objectives on the syllabus. It is a very thorough and thoughtful course, and Professor Weir is a great seminar leader and has great related experience and contacts. This is one of those special courses wherein engagement with guest speakers is common and adds a practical element to an academic study.
Yes
This course was remarkable. A must-take class before graduating!!

I would definitely recommend this class to another student. The course covered a diverse range of topics related to terrorism, and Professor Weir was adept at moderating class discussions. The guest speakers provided unique insights, and through both their expertise and Professor Weir's, I learnt to examine these evocative topics through multiple perspectives.
